notes.Number Systems:
Chapter 1: Number Systems

Natural Numbers (‚Ñï): 1, 2, 3, 4, ...

Whole Numbers (ùïé): 0, 1, 2, 3, ...

Integers (‚Ñ§): ..., -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, ...

Rational Numbers (‚Ñö): Numbers expressible as p/q, where p, q are integers, q ‚â† 0. Example: 1/2, -3/5

Irrational Numbers: Cannot be expressed as p/q. Example: ‚àö2, œÄ

Real Numbers (‚Ñù): All rational and irrational numbers together.

Decimal Expansions: Rational numbers have terminating or repeating decimals. Irrational numbers have non-terminating, non-repeating decimals.

Representation on Number Line: ‚àö2, ‚àö3, etc. can be represented using right triangles.

Laws of Exponents: a^m √ó a^n = a^(m+n), (a^m)^n = a^(mn), a^0 = 1, etc.

Summary: ‚Ñï ‚äÇ ùïé ‚äÇ ‚Ñ§ ‚äÇ ‚Ñö ‚äÇ ‚Ñù. Real numbers can be represented as points on a number line.
